questionText: A woman with essential hypertension presents at 6 weeks gestation. Which of the following anti-hypertensive medications would NOT be appropriate for her to take in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: All of the above would be appropriate for use in pregnancy

questionText: What are potential complications of ACE inhibitor use in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Oligohydramnios, renal failure and fetal hypotension
Decreased skull ossification, hypocalvaria and renal tubular dysgenesis

questionText: Side effects of Methyldopa include which of the following?
At what mean arterial pressure does a loss of cerebral autoregulation occur?
Which of the following medications NOT are suitable for use in a hypertensive crisis?
1g of calcium daily during pregnancy reduces the risk of pre-eclampsia by how much?
For a woman who experiences pre-eclampsia in her first pregnancy, what is her risk of recurrence in her next pregnancy?
Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for pre-eclampsia?
Which of the following are more likely to develop in later life in women who experience pre-eclampsia in pregnancy?
What did the Low-dose Aspirin Study in Pregnancy (CLASP) show?

answers.answerText: Aspirin reduces the risk of early onset pre-eclampsia requiring delivery before 32 weeks gestation
Aspirin reduces the risk of early onset pre-eclampsia requiring delivery before 34 weeks gestation
Aspirin reduces the risk of early onset pre-eclampsia requiring delivery before 37 weeks gestation
Aspirin reduces the risk of late onset pre-eclampsia
Aspirin reduces the risk of late onset pre-eclampsia requiring delivery before 37 weeks gestation

questionText: They HYPITAT study showed which of the following?

answers.answerText: Induction of labour reduced the incidence of severe post-partum haemorrhage
Adverse neonatal outcome was significantly lower in the induction of labour group
The composite score of poor maternal outcome was significantly less in the induction of labour group
Significantly fewer women in the indction of labour group had a caesarean section

questionText: By how much was the risk of eclampsia reduced in women allocated to the MgSO4 group in the MAGPIE trial?
Which of the following were NOT findings of the MAGPIE trial?

answers.answerText: Statistically significant decreased risk of eclampsia in the MgSO4 group
Statsitically significant reduced maternal mortality in the MgSO4 group
Statistically significant reduced rate of placental abruption in the MgSO4 group
Non-significant reduction in the rate of renal failure, liver failure or coagulopathy in the MgSO4 group

questionText: Which of the following is a benefit of epidural anaesthetisia rather than general anaesthetic (GA) for a pre-eclamptic patient who requires a caesarean section?

answers.answerText: Epidural anaesthesia helps reduces fluctuations in blood pressure associated with GA and intubation
Epidural anaesthesia helps increase cardiac pre-load
Epidural anaesthesia is unlikely to worsen oligouria compared to GA
Ergometrine should be avoided with GA but is acceptable to use with epidural anaesthesia

questionText: What is the most likely cause of the clinical features (headache, seizure, confusion, visual loss) seen in posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)?

answers.answerText: Multiple small capillary bleeds in the central nervous system secondary to hypertension
High uric acid levels secondary to uteroplacental ischaemia
Cerebral vasospasm which occurs during and immediately after an eclamptic seizure
Vasogenic oedema in the central nervous system

questionText: What proportion of eclamptic seizures occur intrapartum?
What are the commonest causes of death in pre-eclampsia?

answers.answerText: Cerebral haemorrhage, multi-organ falure, adult respiratory distress syndrome

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a neurological manifestations of pre-eclampsia?
Why are diuretics usually avoided in the treatment of pre-eclampsia?

answers.answerText: The use of diuretics in conjunction with MgSO4 can cause profound hypotension
Diuretics further deplete an already reduced intravascular volume
Diuretics cause hyperkalaemia in pre-eclamptic patients

questionText: When may the use of diuretics be indicated in the treatment of pre-eclampsia?

answers.answerText: When there is idiopathic intracranial hypertension
In all of the above conditions
In none of the above conditions

questionText: What is the mechanism of action of Labetalol?
Which of the following is a contraindication to the use of a MgSO4 infusion?
A patient who is already on a MgSO4 infusion for the prevention of eclampsia, has a seizure. What would be the most appropriate medication to administer next?
What is the therapeutic range for magnesium when used for the prevention of eclampsia?
Which of the following is NOT a sign of magnesium toxicity?
By how much does cardiac output increase during pregnancy?
Which of the following are normal findings in a cardiovascular examination of a pregnant woman?
What is the definition of Class IV of the New York heart association functional classification

answers.answerText: Breathlessness on mild exertion / severely compromised
Breathlessness on moderate extertion / moderately compromised
Breathlessness on severe exertion / mildly compromised

questionText: Which of the following conditions could cause pulmonary hypertension: 1. Cystic Fibrosis; 2. Marfan syndrome; 3. Scleroderma; 4. Mitral stenosis; 5. Primary (idiopathic) pulmonary artery hypertension; 6. Eisenmenger's syndrome
What is the approximate maternal mortality rate of pregnant women with pulmonary hypetension?
A healthy patient at six weeks gestation with a background of a patent ductus arteriosus that was surgically corrected during childhood presents to the hospital. What do you advise her.

answers.answerText: She is suitable for midwifery based care
The condition poses minimal risk to her during pregnancy, however she should have a cardiology review
The condition poses a moderate risk to her and she will require close monitoring during her pregnancy
The condition poses a 10-20% risk of maternal mortality during pregnancy, consider termination
She should have a termination of pregnancy immediately

questionText: If a patient with a medium sized atrial septal defect has an increase in left-to-right flow during delivery, what is likely to occur?
Which of the following is NOT a risk in pregnancy associated with significant congenital aortic stenosis?
What type of medication would be appropriate to use for symptoms of angina, dyspnoea, hypertension and syncope in a pregnant patient with congenital aortic stenosis?
What percentage of patients with Marfan syndrome have cardiac involvement?
What are the most common types of cardiac problems in patients with Marfan syndrome?

answers.answerText: Aortic root dilatation, mitral valve prolapse, mitral regurgitation

questionText: What is the main concern in pregnancy for patients with Marfan syndrome?

answers.answerText: Worsening right to left shunt secondary to ventricular septal defect

questionText: What would be the most appropriate medication to prescribe a patient in pregnancy with Marfan syndrome who has aortic dilatation and hypertension?
What are the risks associated with pregnancy in a patient with cyanotic congenital heart disease?

answers.answerText: Increased right-to-left shunting due to decreased peripheral vascualr resistance in pregnancy, causing worsening cyanosis
Increased thromboembolic risk due to pregnancy and polycythemia
Increased risk of fetal growth restriction +/- fetal loss

questionText: Which of the following correctly describes the abnormalities found in Tetralogy of Fallot?

answers.answerText: Stenosis of the pulmonary valve or artery; ventricular septal defect; aorta connected to the right  ventricle; left ventricular hypertrophy
Stenosis of the aortic valve; ventricular septal defect; overriding aorta connected to the right and left ventricles; right ventricular hypertrophy
Stenosis of the pulmonary valve or artery; ventricular septal defect; overriding aorta connected to the right and left ventricles; right ventricular hypertrophy
Stenosis of the pulmonary valve or artery; atrial septal defect; overriding aorta connected to the right and left ventricles; right ventricular hypertrophy
Stenosis of the pulmonary valve or artery; left ventricular hypoplasia; aorta connected to the right  ventricle; right ventricular hypertrophy

questionText: What is Eisenmenger syndrome?

answers.answerText: Left-to-right shunt, pulmonary hypertension and cyanosis
Right-to-left shunt, pulmonary hypertension and cyanosis
Left-to-right shunt, systemic hypertension and cyanosis
Left-to-right shunt, dilated cardiomyopathy, congestive cardiac failure
Left-to-right shunt, ventricular arrhythmias, congestive cardiac failure

questionText: What is the maternal mortality of patient with Eisenmenger syndrome?
A patient with Eisenmenger syndrome presents for pre-pregnancy counselling. What would be the most appropriate advice?

answers.answerText: Unlikely to experience problems in pregnancy although would require obstetric led care
Small risk of deterioration during pregnancy, needs joint obstetric and cardiology team management
Moderate risk of deterioration towards the end of pregnancy, small risk of maternal mortality in developed countries
Significant risk of deterioration during in the late second or third trimester of pregnancy, likely to require early delivery, maternal mortality unlikely
Significant risk of maternal mortality, pregnancy contraindicated

questionText: Why is tachycadia dangerous in pregnant women with mitral stenosis?

answers.answerText: Diastolic filling of the left ventricle decreases, there is a fall in stroke volume and a rise in left atrial pressure resulting in pulmonaary oedema
Diastolic filling of the right ventricle decreases, there is a fall in stroke volume and a rise in right atrial pressure resulting in pulmonaary oedema
Tachycardia can precipitate paroxysmal noctural dyspnoea and orthopnoea
Risk of paradoxical thromboembolic increases, increasing the risk of ischaemic strok
A previously small and clinically insignificant ventricular septal defect can enlarge causing right-to-left shunting

questionText: What medication would be appropriate to prescribe to a pregnant patient with mitral stenosis who is tachycardic?
What medication would be appropriate to prescribe to a pregnant patient with mitral stenosis who develops shortness of breath secondary to pulmonary oedema?
What medications are appropriate to use in pregnant women with atrial fibrillation?

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is the development of significant left ventricular systolic dysfunction without a known cause in a patient who had no heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy. When does it occur?

answers.answerText: During the last month of pregnancy to one month post-partum
During the last month of pregnancy to six weeks post-partum
During the last month of pregnancy to up to five months post-partum

questionText: Without thromboprophylaxis, what percentage of patients with peripartum cardiomyopathy will develop embolism?
What happens to fibrinogen levels during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Initial decrease in first trimester, then normalise
Initial increse in first trimester, then normalise

questionText: What happens to clotting factors XIII, IX and X during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Initial decrease in first trimester, then normalise
Initial increse in first trimester, then normalise

questionText: What happens to anetithrombin and protein S levels during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Initial decrease in first trimester, then normalise
Initial increse in first trimester, then normalise

questionText: Which of the following is correct regarding DVTs during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: DVTs occur on either side with equal frequency
DVTs occur in the left leg more frequently than in the right leg, as the gravid uterus is more likely to compress the left iliac vein
DVTs occur in the right leg more frequently than in the right leg, as the gravid uterus is more likley to compress the right iliac vein
DVTs occur on the left more frequently as there is increased venous stasis due to compression of the left iliac ven by the right iliac artery and ovarian artery
DVTs occur on the right more frequently as there is increased venous stasis due to compression of the right iliac ven by the left iliac artery and ovarian artery

questionText: When is the period of greatest risk for developing venous thromboembolism?
In the context of a pulmonary embolism, what might ECG reveal?

answers.answerText: Normal sinus rhythm, a sinus tachycardia or a S1, Q3, T3 pattern
Right axis deviation or right bundle branch block
Peaked P waves in lead II or Q waves in the inferior leads
ST segment changes in the anterior leads, T wave inversion

questionText: What would be an appropriate therapeutic dose of Enoxaparin (Clexane) in a 60kg woman with a pulmonary embolism?
How can Enoxaparin (Clexane) levels be monitored?
How can unfractionated heparin levels be monitored?
What is a benefit of using Enoxaparin (Clexane) over unfractionated heparin when therapeutic anticoagulation is required?

answers.answerText: Ability to more rapidly reverse if required

questionText: When long term anti-coagulation is required, what is an advantage of using Enoxaparin (Clexane) over unfractionated heparin?

answers.answerText: Ability to more rapidly reverse if required

questionText: At what gestation is the main teratogenic risk from Warfarin?
When do women with metal prosthetic heart valve replacements require full anticoagulation?

answers.answerText: Throughout the whole pregnancy and postpartum

questionText: Are Enoxaparin (Clexane) and Warfarin contraindicated whilst breastfeeding?

answers.answerText: Enoxaparin is contraindicated but Warfarin is not
Warfarin is contraindicated by Enoxaparin is not
Neither is contraindicated whilst breastfeeding although both are excreted in breast milk
Neither is contraindicated whilst breastfeeding, neither is excreted in breast milk

questionText: What is the approximate incidence of cerebral vein thrombosis?
Which of the following are NOT symptoms of cerebral vein thrombosis?

answers.answerText: Signs of raised intracranial pressure, impaired consciousness
All of the above can be signs of cerebral vein thrombosis

questionText: What is the best imaging modality to image a cerebral vein thrombosis?
By how much does the consumption of oxygen increase during pregnancy?
Which of the following is normal in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: A mild fully compensated respiratory alkalosis
A mild fully compensated respiratory acidosis

questionText: What is the incubation period of varicella?
What proportionof women infected with chicken pox during pregnancy will develop varicella pneumonia?
If a patient presents with pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP), exposure to which virus would you suspect?
What is the approximate carrier rate of cystic fibrosis in caucasians?
Which of the following features is NOT predictive of a poor obstetric outcome in a patient with cystic fibrosis?
What proportion of adult patients with cystic fibrosis have pancreatic insufficiency?
What proportion of adult patients with cystic fibrosis have diabetes?
Which of the following is NOT a possible fetal complication of poorly controlled type 1 diabetes?
Which of the following is NOT a possible maternal complication of poorly controlled type 1 diabetes?
What is the most common cause of maternal mortality in diabetic mothers?
What rare congenital anomaly is associated with diabetes?
Why can hyperemesis gravidarum cause a biochemical hyperthyroidism?

answers.answerText: Because human chorionic gonadotrophin is structurally similar to thyroid stimulating hormone, and has TSH-like activity
Because human chorionic gonadotrophin is structurally similar to thyroxine, and has thyroxine-like activity
Because patients with subclinical hyperthyroidism are more prone to hyperemesis gravidarum
Because malnutrition secondary to hyperemesis gravidarum can depress TSH levels
Because dehydration concentrates the blood and gives a falsely elevated T4 reading

questionText: Severe iodine deficiency in pregnancy can result in which syndrome?
Which of the following is NOT associated with cretinism?

answers.answerText: Cognitive impairment ranging from mild to severe

questionText: Typical features of hyperthyroidism are common in normal pregnancy. Which of the following features can be used to discriminate hyperthyroidism from normal pregnancy symptoms?
What proportion of cases of hyperthyroidism in pregnancy are caused by Graves disease?
Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder caused by which antibodies?
Poorly controlled thyrotoxicosis can result in which of the following conditions?
What percentage of babies born to mothers with Graves disease suffer from fetal or neonatal thyrotoxicosis secondary to the transplacental passage of TRAbs?
The fetus of a mother with Graves disease develops a goitre. What is this cause of this?

answers.answerText: TSH receptor stimulating hormone antibodies (TRAb) cross the placenta, stimulate the fetal thyroid gland and cause a fetal hyperthyroidism
Medications such as Carbimazole and propylthiouracil (PTU) cross the placenta and cause a fetal hypothryroidism
TRAb from uncontrolled Graves disease cross the placenta, continued stimulation increases the risk of thyroid cancer in the fetus

questionText: What rare fetal condition can Carbimazole (used to treat hyperthyroidism) cause in the fetus?
Which of the following is NOT a cause of hypothyroidism?

answers.answerText: Graves disease treated with radioiodine therapy

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a potential consequence of untreated hypothyroidism?
What is the definition of subclinical hypothyroidism?

answers.answerText: Low TSH (<5th centile) with high T4
High TSH (>97.5th centile) with a normal T4
High TSH (>95th centile) with a low T4
Low TSH (<2.5th centile) with a normal T4
Undetectable TSH with a normal T4

questionText: What percentage of women with thyroid peroxidase antibodies will develop postpartum thyroiditis?
Of women who develop postpartum thyroiditis, what proportion experience a biphasic pattern, ie, initially become hyperthyroid, then become hypothyroid
What should a patient with symptomatic hyperthyroidism due to postpartum thyroiditis be treated with?
By how much are vitamin D requirements increased in pregnancy?
What effect can maternal hyperparathyroidism have on the neonate?

answers.answerText: Tetany, convulsions and hypocalcaemia secondary to suppression of fetal parathyroid hormone by high maternal calcium levels'
Vitamin D deficiency, poor bone mineralisation due to hypocalcaemia
Excessive bone growth due to excessively high calcium levels in utero - overgrowth of jaw and hip joints common
Microvascular calcium deposits causing ischaemia to peripheral digits, renal calculi, permanent renal damage, secondary to prolonged high calcium levels

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a risk associated with untreated hypocalcaemia secondary to hypoparathyroidism in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Fetal bone demineralisation and neonatal rickets

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for vitamin D deficiency?
How much do prolactin levels increase during pregnancy?
What happens to luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) levels during pregnancy?

Which of the following can be symptoms of prolactinoma: 1. Amenorrhoea, 2. Tachycardia, 3. Headaches, 4. Visual field defects (bitemporal hemianopia), 5. Diabetes insipidus, 6. Galactorrhoea, 7. Intrauterine fetal growth restriction
What is the most common cause of hyperprolactinaemia?
What would be the most appropriateway to monitor a macroprolactinoma in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Serial examinations looking for the presence of galactorrhoea

questionText: How are plasma and urine osmolality altered in diabetes insipidus?

answers.answerText: Plasma osmolality is increased and urine osmolality is decreased
Plasma osmolality is decreased and urine osmolality is increased
Plasma osmolality is unchanged and urine osmolality is increased
Plasma osmolality is increased and urine osmolality is increased
Plasma osmolality is decreased and urine osmolality is decreased

questionText: There are four types of diabetes insipidus. Which of the following is NOT a type.

answers.answerText: Central - due to deficienct production of anti-diuretic hormone from the posterior pituitary
Nephrogenic - due to anti-diuretic hormone resistance
Transient - due to increased vasopressinase production by the placenta, or decreased vasopressinase by the liver
Psychogenic - due to compulsive drinking of water and consequent polyuria
Cardiogenic - release of vasopressinase by cardiac myocytes exposed to ischaemia can break down anti-diuretic hormone in the blood

questionText: According to the 'new' diagnostic criteria for gestational diabetes published by ADIPS and IADPSG, a fasting blood sugar level above what level is diagnostic of gestational diabetes?

According to the 'new' diagnostic criteria for gestational diabetes published by ADIPS and IADPSG, a one hour blood sugar value equal to or higher than what level during a glucose tolerance test is diagnostic of gestational diabetes?

According to the 'new' diagnostic criteria for gestational diabetes published by ADIPS and IADPSG, a two hour blood sugar value equal to or higher than what level during a glucose tolerance test is diagnostic of gestational diabetes?
What happens to insulin production and insulin resistance in a normal pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Increase in production, increase in resistance

questionText: In women with diabetes, what is the most common cause of maternal death?
Diabetic ketoacidosis is rare in pregnancy, however some factors increase the risk of it occurring. Which of the following factors does NOT increase the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis?

answers.answerText: Corticosteroid administration to promote fetal lung maturity

questionText: What is the cause of the severe oedema that can occur in women with diabetic nephropathy?
For diabetic women with a HbA1C level of >10% at the time of conception, what is the risk of congenital anomalies?

answers.answerText: No increase in risk above that of the non-diabetic population

questionText: For diabetic women with a HbA1C level of <8% at the time of conception, what is the risk of congenital anomalies?

answers.answerText: No increase in risk above that of the non-diabetic population

questionText: For diabetic women with a HbA1C normal level at the time of conception, what is the risk of congenital anomalies?

answers.answerText: No increase in risk above that of the non-diabetic population

questionText: Are the fetus's of diabetic mothers at increased risk of sudden unexplained intrauterine death?

answers.answerText: Yes, regardless of the degree of diabetic control
No, regardless of the degree of diabetic control
Yes, but it is inversely related to the degree of diabetic control
Yes, but it is positively related to the degree of diabetic control
Only in women with type 1 diabetes, no increased risk in women with type 2 diabetes

questionText: What is the approximate risk of fetal mortality if diabetic ketoacidosis occurs?
What is the approximate risk of fetal mortality if mild maternal hypoglycaemia occurs?
Which othe following is OT a consequence (direct or indirect) of fetal hyperinsulinaemia in the fetuses of women with poorly controlled diabetes?

answers.answerText: Chronic fetal hypoxia leading to fetal polycythemia

questionText: What is the main risk of tight blood sugar control of diabetic women in pregnancy?
What proportion of patients with diabetic nephropathy will develop hypertension in pregnancy?
What is the risk of congenital malformations in the fetuses of women with gestational diabetes?

answers.answerText: No increase in risk above that of the non-diabetic population

questionText: A woman has a large post-partum haemorrhage during which time she becomes extremely hypotensve. Consequently she develops Sheehan's syndrome. What clinical symptoms might she develop?

answers.answerText: Loss of axillary and pubic hair

questionText: Which of the following are NOT clinical features of Cushing's syndrome?
Which of the following is NOT a potential implications of Cushings syndrome in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Increased risk of neonatal adrenal insufficiency
Increased risk of vitamin D deficiency in the neonate
Increased risk of wound infection after caesarean section

questionText: Which of the following are clinical features of Conn's syndrome (hyperaldosteronism)?
Why is Spironolactone contraindicated in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Increased risk of neural tube defects
Risk of feminisation of a male fetus

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a clinical feature associated with phaeochromocytoma in pregnancy?
How can a phaeochromocytoma be diagnosed in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Increased cortisol level that is not suppressed with a high dose dexmethasone suppression test
Low serum potassium level and suppressed renin activity
MIBG (131I-meta-iodobenzylguanidine) scan to localize noreadrenaline uptake

questionText: What deficiencies occur in Addison's disease?

answers.answerText: Deficiency of growth hormone and thyrotropin releasing hormones
Deficiency of lutenizing hormone and follicle stimulating hormone

questionText: What effect does pregnancy have on Addison's disease?

answers.answerText: Rapid expansion in the size of the pituitary lesion

questionText: Which of the following blood test abnormalities in NOT likley to be present in a pregnant patient with Addison's disease?
What antibodies are associated with Sjogren's syndrome?
What is the effect of pregnancy on rheumatoid arthritis?

answers.answerText: The majority of women experience an improvement in symptoms
The majority of women experience an deterioration in symptoms
Pregnany has no impact on the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis
A third of women experience an improvement, a third experience a deterioration and a third are unchanged

questionText: How is the miscarriage rate altered above the baseline rate in women with rheumatoid arthritis?
Of women with rheumatoid arthritis who experience an improvement in symptoms during pregnancy, what percentage experience a postprtum exacerbation?
Which of the following is a rare complication of general anaesthetic for caesarean section in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
Which of the following is NOT a risk of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) use in the third trimester of pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
All of the above are risks of NSAID use

questionText: Which of the following medications is safe for use throughout pregnancy for treatment of a mother with rheumatoid arthritis?
What proportion of women with SLE have anti-Ro or anti-La antibodies?
What is the most common auto-antibody found in pregnant women with SLE?
At what stage of pregnancy do SLE flares occur?

answers.answerText: At any stage of pregnancy or the puerperium

questionText: Regarding attempts to conceive, what advice should women with SLE be given?

answers.answerText: Delay attempts to conceive for six months after a lupus flare
Delay to attempts to conceive for twelve months after a lupus flare
Pregnancy has no effect on the likelihood of a flare
Pregnancy should be avoided in women who have a history of a lupus nephritis flare
Pregnancy should be avoided in all women who have SLE

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a risk associated with SLE in pregnancy?
Which of the following is suggestive of a SLE flare during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Rising anti-DNA antibody titres and a fall in complement level
Symptoms such as arthralgia, malar skin rash and pleuritic pain
Proteinuria and a deterioration in renal function

questionText: What is the only reliable way to definitely distinguish between pre-eclampsia and a flare of SLE?

answers.answerText: Worsening of proteinuria suggests a SLE flare
Abnormal liver function tests suggest a flare of SLE

questionText: What pre-pregnancy factors increase the likelihood of a poor outcome in pregnancy in a patient with SLE?

answers.answerText: Flare of lupus nephritis within six months of conception
Presence of anti-Ro or anti-La antibodies

questionText: In a patient with SLE who has anti-Ro antibodies, what is the risk of congenital heart block?
In a patient with SLE who has anti-Ro antibodies, what is the risk of transient neonatal cutaneous lupus?
How long does it take for the rash assoicated with neontal lupus to resolve?
How long does it take for the congenital heart block assoicated with SLE to resolve?
What percentage of patients with SLE have anti-phospholipid antibodies?

The diagnosis of anti-phospholipid syndrome requires the presence of anti-cardiolipin or lupus anticoagulant plus either a thrombotic or a pregnancy morbidity characteristic. Which of the following is NOT a thrombotic characteristic?

answers.answerText: All of the above are thrombotic classifications

questionText: The diagnosis of anti-phospholipid syndrome requires the presence of anti-cardiolipin or lupus anticoagulant plus either a thrombotic or a pregnancy morbidity characteristic. Which of the following is NOT a pregnancy morbidity characteristic?

answers.answerText: One or more fetal death at greater than 10 weeks gestation with normal fetal morphology
One or more fetal death at greater than 10 weeks gestation
Three or more consecutive miscarriages at less than 10 weeks gestation
One or more premature births at <34 weeks with normal fetal morphology due to pre-eclampsia or severe placental insufficiency
All of the above are thrombotic classifications

questionText: Which of the following are required for the diagnosis of anti-phospholipid syndrome?

answers.answerText: Anti-cardiolipin antibodies and/or beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies
Beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies and/or lupus anticoagulant
Anti-cardiolipin antibodies, beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies and/or lupus anticoagulant

questionText: Other features associated with anti-phospholipid syndrome aside from thrombosis and pregnancy morbidity include which of the following?

answers.answerText: Heart valve disease, hypertension and leg ulcers
Cerebral involvement including epilepsy, cerebral infarction and migraine
All of the above are associated with anti-phospholipid syndrome

questionText: Diagnosis of anti-phospholipid syndrome requires two or more positive readings for anti-cardolipin antibodies and/or lupus anticoagulant at least how far apart?
Anti-phospholipid syndrome increases the risk of several adverse outcomes in pregnancy. Which of the following is NOT at increased risk?

answers.answerText: First trimester miscarriage, or fetal death in the second or third trimester
There is an increased risk of all of the above

questionText: Which of the following medications would you initiate as soon as pregnancy is confirmed in a patient with anti-phospholipid antibodies (anti-cardiolipin and/or lupus anticoagulant) but who do not have anti-phospholipid syndrome?
In addition to low dose aspirin, what medicaton would you administer throughout pregnancy to a patient who has anti-phospholipid syndrome with a history of venous throboembolism?

answers.answerText: Therapeutic low molecular weight heparin (eg, Enoxaparin)

questionText: Which of the following is NOT an important clinical features of anti-phospholipid syndrome?

answers.answerText: Fetal death in the second or third trimester

questionText: Which of the following are characteristics of CREST syndrome?

answers.answerText: Cortical blindness which is reversible, eclampsia, seizures and thrombocytopenia
Clubbing, respiratory distress, epilepsy, salt wasting and thrombosis
Calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, oesophageal involvement, sclerodactyly, telangiectasia
Cataracts, retinopathy, encephalitis, seizures, thrombocytopenic purpura
Cognitive deficit, retinal calcification, epilepsy, sclerodactyly, thromobcytopenia

questionText: What are the different forms of scleroderma?

answers.answerText: Localised cutaneous, systemic sclerosis, CREST syndrome
Localised cutaneous, cerebral, lung and kidney
Raynaud's phenomena, oesophageal and cardiac involvement

questionText: Which of the following organs may be invovled in systemic sclerosis secondary to scleroderma?
What impact does pregnancy have on Raynaud's disease?

answers.answerText: One third improve, one third are unchanged, one third deteriorate
Tends to be an improvement due to vasodilation and increased blood flow
Tends to be a deterioration due to the hypercoagulative state of pregnancy
Risk of ischaemia to digits increases significantly

questionText: What is the maternal risk associated with systemic sclerosis with renal involvement during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Digital ischaemia secondary to deterioration of Raynaud's phenomena
Atlanto-axial subluxation during intubation if general anaesthetic for caesarean section is required

questionText: If a patient with scleroderma suffers from reflux oesophagitis pre-pregnancy, what may occur during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Deterioration due to lowered oesophageal tone

questionText: There are several potential anaesthetic issues with pregnant patients who have scleroderma. Which of the following is NOT of particular concern?

answers.answerText: Difficult intubation secondary to limitation of mouth opening plus difficult venous access secondary to skin involvement
Difficulty with epidural placement due to skin involvement on the back
General anaesthetia can be tricky in patients with severe pulmonary fibrosis and pulmonary hypertension
Cardiac arrhythmias or death due to cardiac dysfunction with general anaesthesia
High risk of oesophageal involvement and reflux in patients with systemic involvement

questionText: If a patient with severe pulmonary fibrois and pulmonary hypertension secondary to scleroderma consults you for pre-pregnancy counselling, what should you advise?

answers.answerText: Advise pregnancy is likely to result in an improvement of symptoms and midwifery based care would be appropriate
Advise pregnancy is likely to result in an improvement of symptoms and is safe provided it is managed by obstetricians
Pregnany is unlikely to have any impact on their disease status so provided they are well pre-pregnancy, pregnancy is safe
Pregnancy is likely to result in a deterioration of symptoms so needs to be managed by obstetricians
Advise against pregnancy and ensure patient has a reliable form of contraception

questionText: What is the mortality rate in pregnancy of patients with type IV (ecchymotic or arterial) Ehers-Danlos syndrome (defect of collagen metabolism disease)?

answers.answerText: Not raised above the baseline risk

questionText: Which of the following is NOT at increased risk in labouring patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndome (defect of collagen metabolism disease)?

answers.answerText: Severe tears of the vagina and/or perineum

questionText: If a patient with epilepsy continues her medication during pregnancy, what is likely to happen to the frequency of her seizures?

answers.answerText: Unlikely to have any seizures during pregnancy

questionText: In patients with epilepsy, when are seizures most likely to occur?
Which of the following is NOT a likely reason to explain an epileptic patient having increased seizure frequency in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Lack of compliance with anti-convulsant medications due to fears regarding teratogenicity
Decreased free drug levels due vomiting in early pregnancy or labour
Decreased absorption of anti-convulsant medications during labour

questionText: What is the likely effect on a fetus of a mother having a short tonic-clonic epileptic seizure?

answers.answerText: No long term effect although a fetal bradycardia may occur
Significantly increased risk of cerebral palsy
Risk of placental abruption and/or fetal trauma such as limb fracture
Increased risk of premature rupture of the membranes
Risk of fetal death due to hypoxia secondary to the seizure

questionText: If a mother has epilepsy (no structural cause identified), what is the likelihood of her child being affected with epilepsy?
If a mother and father both have epilepsy (no structural cause identified), what is the likelihood of their child being affected with epilepsy?
If a mother has epilepsy (no structural cause identified) and already has one child affecte with epilepsy, what is the likelihood of her next child being affected with epilepsy?
Which of the following anti-convulsant medications does NOT cross the placenta?
Why are Cabergline and Bromocriptine (Dopamine receptor agonists) problematic whilst a patient is breastfeeding?

answers.answerText: Can cause fetal drowsiness and/or respiratory depression

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a concern regarding the use of anti-convulsant medications in epileptic mothers during pregnancy?
Which of the following anti-convulsant medications is the most likely to cause fetal malformations?
Which of the following is NOT an appropriate strategy to reduce the risk of teratogenicity from an anti-convulsant medication taken by a woman with epilepsy wanting pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Recommend 5mg of folic acid daily pre-pregnancy and during pregnancy
With the supervision of a neurologist, change a patient's sodium valproate to a different anti-convulsant medication
With the supervision of a neurologist, reduce the dose of anti-epileptic medicaitons to the minimum effective dose
Cease the patient's anti-convulsant medications as soon as pregnacy is confirmed

questionText: What medication should women be prescribed in the last four weeks of pregnancy if they are taking a hepatic enzyme inducing medication (eg, anti-convulsant medication)?
What proportion of women with epilepsy will have a seizure during labour?
If a patient has an epileptic seizure that is not rapidly self-limiting, what would the most appropriate medication to administer?
What medication should all neonates of mothers with epilepsy who are medicated with an anti-convulsant medication be given?
What would an effective contraceptive for a woman taking a hepatic enzyme inducing medication (eg, anti-convulsant)?

answers.answerText: Combined oral contraceptive pill containing 30mcg ethinyloestradiol
Combined oral contraceptive pill containing 50mcg ethinyloestradiol
Progesterone only pill containing 15mcg of levonorgestrel

questionText: What proportion of women with a history of migraine have an improvement during pregnancy?
What is the effect of pregnancy on multiple sclerosis?

answers.answerText: Increase in relapse rate during pregnancy, return to baseline rate post-partum
No effect on the relapse rate
Decrease in relapse rate during pregnancy, return to baseline rate post-partum
Decrease in relapse rate during pregnancy, rate increases markedly in the 3 months post-partum
Causes a permanent progression in the disease state

questionText: In myasthenia gravis, IgG antibodies to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor block neuromuscular transmission. What is the consequence of this?

answers.answerText: Impaired first stage of labour necessitating caesarean section for delivery
Thyroid dysfunction in >90% of women with myasthenia gravis

questionText: Which of the following medications are contraindicated in patients with myasthenia gravis?

answers.answerText: Drugs that may block neuromuscular transmission, eg, beta-blockers
Drugs that impair neuromuscular transmission and increase weakness, eg, amnioglycoside antibiotics such as gentamicin
Magnesium sulphate infusions as it may precipitate a crisis
Drugs that my exacerbate muscle fatigue, eg, beta-adrenergics such as salbutamol, or narcotics

questionText: By how much does the incidence of Bell's palsy increase during pregnancy?

In Bell's palsy, there is unilateral facial weakness (making the patient unable to wrinkle her forehead on the affected side) +/- pain or loss of taste on the anterior two thirds of the tongue. Which nerve is affected?
Outside of pregnancy, Bell's palsy is usually caused by the herpes virus. During late pregnancy/peripartum, another etiology is likely. What is this etiology?

answers.answerText: Swelling of the facial nerve within the temporal bone

questionText: What proportion of Bell's palsies that occur in pregnancy improve spontaneously?
Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) presents with what symptoms?
What is the cause of posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)?
What proportion of pregnant women are affected by carpal tunnel syndrome?
What is the etiology of carpal tunnel syndrome?

answers.answerText: Direct effect of oestrogen on the median nerve
Compression of the median nerve at the flexor retinaculum

questionText: What is Phalen's sign?

answers.answerText: Pain in the right lower quadrant with palpation of the left lower quadrant
Flexion of the hip and knee with interal rotation of the right hip to eleicit right lower quadrant pain
Tenderness 5cm proximal/medial from the anterior superior iiac spine
Reproduction of carpal tunnel symptoms with sustained flexion of the wrist
Combination of cortical blindess, hypertension, headaches and seizures

questionText: Up to what pelvicalceal diameter is hydronephrosis considered normal in pregnancy?
By how much does renal plasma flow increase during pregnancy?
What is the upper limit of protein excretion in the urine that is considered normal in pregnancy?
What is the most common bacterial cause of urinary tract infection in pregnancy?
Which of the following is NOT recommended as a means of reducing the risk of urinary tract infection in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Voiding after sexual intercourse to 'flush away' organisms
Double voiding to minimize residual volume in the bladder
Low dose prophylactic antibiotics if a patient has a history of recurrent UTIs
Wiping from 'back to front' after opening bowels

questionText: Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy increases the risk of which of the following?
Which of the following adverse outcomes is NOT associated with chronic kidney disease in pregnancy?
Which of the following complications is NOT an effect of pregnancy on chronic kidney disease?
Which of the following is NOT at increased risk in a pregnant patient with chronic kidney disease?
In a pregnant patient with chronic renal impairment, what can be the consequence of the high maternal urea level?

answers.answerText: Fetal seizures due to the action of high urea levels on the fetal brain
Lowered IQ as the high urea load can be directly toxic to the fetal brain
Polyhydramnios secondary to fetal polyria due to high osmotic load
Fetal bone deformities due to low fetal vitamin D levels
Polycystic hyperplastic fetal kidneys due to urea overload

questionText: For a patient with renal failure requiring dialysis, what is the perinatal mortality rate?
For a patient with severe renal failure and a creatinine >180mcg/L, what is the likelihood the patient will require preterm delivery?
What percentage of patients with glomeronephritis have a progressive decline in their renal function during pregnancy?
Of women with glomeronephritis who have normal renal function at the time of conception, how does pregnancy effect the course of development of end stage renal failure?

answers.answerText: 5% chance of progression to renal failure during pregnancy
10% chance of progression to renal failure during pregnancy
25% chance of progression to renal failure during pregnancy
Pregnancy is contraindicated due to high risk of non-reversable end stage renal failure

questionText: What should pregnant women with reflux nephropathy be regularly screen for?
What proportion of pregnant women with reflux nephropathy, normal renal fucntion and without hypertension, will develop pre-eclampsia?
What condition may the babies of mothers with reflux nepropathy develop?
Which of the following contribute to the development of anaemia in pregnant patients with diabetic nephropathy?

answers.answerText: Deficiency of erythropoeitin secretion and haemodilution

questionText: What is the effect of pregnancy on diabetic nephropathy?

answers.answerText: It does not usually increase the rate of deterioration in renal function
Significantly increases the rate of renal deterioration
Causes an improvement in renal function
Pregnancy increases the likelihood of the development of renal cell carcinoma
Pregnancy is contratindicate d in women with diabetic nephropathy

questionText: What is the likelihood of a mother with polycystic kidney disease passing the condition on to her son?

answers.answerText: 0% as this condition occurs as a result of spontaneous mutations
25% as it occurs secondary to a Robertsonian translocation
50% as it is an autosomal dominant condition
100% as it is an X linked condiition
It is autosomal recessive so she can only pass it on if her husband is a carrier

questionText: What is the effect of chronic kidney disease requiring dialysis on fertility?

answers.answerText: No impact on conception although almost all miscarry in the first trimester

questionText: Which of the following is NOT at increased risk during the pregnancy of a patient with chronic kidney disease requiring haemodialysis?

answers.answerText: Reduced fertility, increased risk of miscarriage
Hypertension, pre-eclampsia, fetal death in utero
Polyhydramnios secondary to uraemia, preterm labour, preterm rupture of the membranes
Bleeding secondary to full heparinisation required for dialysis, placental abruption
Increased proteinuria causing hypoalbuminaemia and nephrotic syndrome

questionText: What is a problem with chronic ambulatory peritoneal dialysis in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Increased miscarriage rate over that of haemodialysis
Increased risk of bleeding and placental abruption
Limitation in the volume of exchanges in later pregnancy
Increased risk of preterm labour and delivery

questionText: What happens to required frequency of dialysis during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Significantly increased frequency of dialysis is required
Frequency of dialysis is not affected by pregnancy
Frequency of dialysis is reduced due to the haemodilution that occurs in pregnancy

questionText: How long after a woman has had a renal transplant should she be advised against falling pregnant?

answers.answerText: Can start to try to conceive immediately
Pregnancy should not be recommended under any circumstances

questionText: If a patient has had a successful renal transplant, has normal renal function and has reached the second trimester without any significant complications, how likely is it that she will have a good pregnancy outcome?
If a patient has had a successful renal transplant and her baseline creatinine is <100, what effect is her pregnancy like to have on the survival of her transplanted kidney?
Which of the following is NOT true about renal transplants and pregnancy?

answers.answerText: The chance of a good outcome is >95% if a patient has a baseline creatinine of <125 and reaches the second trimester without complication
The likelihood of pre-eclampsia, fetal growth restriction and preterm delivery are increased if renal function is abnormal or the patient is hypertensive prior to pregnancy
If a patient has had an episode of graft rejection immediately prior to conceiving, the likelihood of a good pregnancy outcome is reduced
The rate of complications in pregnancy is generally the same regardless of the cause of the renal failure
It is important to monitor creatinine, proteinuria, blood pressure, albumin, bicarbonate, calcium, haemoglobin and platelet levels throughout pregnancy

questionText: Which of the following is NOT a likely cause of deteriorating renal function in a pregnant patient who has had a renal transplant four years prior to her pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Renal damage secondary to the development of gestational diabetes

questionText: What are features suggestive of acute rejection in a pregnant patient with a renal transplant?
Which of the following medications is NOT considered relatively safe in pregnancy?
Why is mycophenolate mofetil contraindicated in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: May cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

questionText: If a patient is taking oral steriods for any reason during pregnancy, which of the following should be administered during labour?

answers.answerText: Continue the current dose of oral steroids
Double the current dose of oral steriods
Cease steroids during labour then recommence at the same dose after delivery
Cease steroids during labour then recommence at a tapering dose after delivery

questionText: Which of the following is NOT likely to be a cause of a patient's acute kidney injury during pregnancy/delviery?

answers.answerText: Infection, eg, septic miscarriage, sepsis in pregnancy; medications eg, NSAIDs, antibiotics
Use of hepatic enzyme inducting medications such as anti-convulsant medications
Large volume blood loss with massive transfusion
Ureteric damage at the time of caesarean section
Pre-eclampsia, HELLP syndrome or acute fatty liver

questionText: What blood test abnormalities may be present in a patient with an acute kidney injury?
Why do levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) increase during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Due to breakdown of bone releasing ALP
Due to fetal excretion of ALP and its transfer across the placenta
Due to placental production of ALP

questionText: Which of the following acute infections is most likely to cause an elevation in iiver function tests?
If a mother has hepatitis B and is surface antigen (HBsAg) and e-antigen (HbeAg) positive and her baby receives no intervention at birth, what is the likelihood of the baby contracting hepatitis B?
At birth, what medications should be given to the baby of a hepatitis B infected mother?

answers.answerText: Hep B immune globulin and Hep B vaccination
Tenofovir, Hep B immune globulin and Hep B vaccination
Lamotrogine, Hep B immune globulin and Hep B vaccination

questionText: What condition are hepatitis C women at increased risk of developing during pregnancy?
How is hepatitis A usually transmitted?
What is the risk of fulminant hepatic failure in a pregnant woman who acquires a hepatitis E infection?
Which of the following is a correct statement regarding the herpes simplex virus (HSV)?

answers.answerText: A mild elevation in liver transaminases and a significant prolongation of the prothrombin time occurs with primary HSV 2 infection
A primary HSV 2 infection is a rare cause of fulmanant hepatits in pregnant women and this has a high mortality rate
A primary HSV 2 infection will only cause fulminant hepatitis if a patient already has a HSV 1 infection
Antiviral therapy is of no benefit in a disseminated HSV 2 infection
Only a primary infection with HSV 1 can result in fulminant liver failure

questionText: When does pruritis secondary to obstetric cholestasis usually occur?

answers.answerText: Equally likely to occur at any of the above times

questionText: If obstetric cholestasis develops in a hepatitis C positive woman, when is it likely to present?

answers.answerText: At a later gestation than in hepatitis C negative women
At an earlier gestation than in hepatitis C negative women
At a similar gestation to hepatitis C negative women
Obstetric cholestasis is unlikely to occur in hepatitis C women unless they are co-infected with HIV
Obstetric cholestasis is unlikely to occur in hepatitis C positive women

questionText: What type of contraception should be avoided in women who experience obstetric cholestasis during pregnancy?
Which of the following is an effective way of monitoring fetal wellbeing in pregnancy complicated by obstetric cholestasis in order to avoid stillbirth?

answers.answerText: Weekly growth and wellbeing ultrasounds with Doppler blood flow analysis
Close monitoring of bile acid concentrations

questionText: For a woman who develops obstetric cholestasis in her first pregnancy, what is the recurrence rate of obstetric cholestasis in future pregnancies?
What is the approximate incidence of acute fatty liver of pregnancy?
What proportion of women with acute fatty liver of pregnancy have a coagulopathy?
At what gestation does acute fatty liver of pregnancy usually present?

answers.answerText: Third trimester, often close to term

questionText: What proportion of women with acute fatty liver of pregnancy develop hypoglycaemia?
Which of the following is NOT a possible complication of HELLP syndrome?

answers.answerText: Subcapsular liver haematoma, liver rupture or massive liver necrosis
Anaemia secondary to haemolysis causing an elevated lactate dehydrogenase

questionText: Which of the following blood tests abnormalities are NOT likely to be present in a patient with hyperemesis gravidarum?
Why is the human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level inversely correlated with the thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level in early pregnancy?

answers.answerText: hCG directly acts on the thyrotropin releasing hormone receptor to inhibit the release of TSH
Thyroxine and hCG have a similar structure and therefore hCG acts on the TSH to inhibit its release
Raised levels of hCG cause hyperemesis and TSH is lost in the vomitus
hCG shares a common subunit with TSH, causing a cross reactivity whereby hCG stimulates the release of thyroxine

questionText: What is the least likely cause of vomiting which commences in the third trimester?
Wernike's encephalopathy can occur secondary to hyperemesis gravidarum. To avoid this condition, patients admitted with hyperemesis should be supplemented with which of the following vitamins?
Rapid correction of hyponatraemia can result in which of the following conditions?
What type of IV fluids may precipitate Wernike's encephalopathy when given to a patient suffering from severe hyperemesis?
Which of the following is NOT an appropriate medication to prescribe for nausea and vomiting in pregnancy?
What is the likelihood of recurrence of hyperemesis in future pregnancies?

answers.answerText: Nil, it only occurs in a patient's first ongoing pregnancy
Small, it is usually milder in subsequent pregnancies
Very high recurrence rate, almost certain to recur

questionText: Which of the following sites does ulcerative colitis affect?

answers.answerText: It can affect any of the above

questionText: Which of the following sites does Crohn's disease affect?

answers.answerText: It can affect any of the above

questionText: What is the risk of exacerbation of ulcerative colitis during pregnancy?
Sulfasalazine is a dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor. It is safe to use in pregnancy for patients with ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease provided which of the following conditions is met?

answers.answerText: The patient is receiving 500mcg of folate daily
The patient is receiving 5mg of folate daily
It is not used in the first trimester
It is not used in the third trimester
It is not used whilst the patient is breastfeeding

questionText: What is the primary management of coeliac disease during pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Strict adherence to a gluten-free diet
Sulfasalazine can be safely used to treat flares
Corticosteroids can be safely used to treat flares
Close obstetric monitoring due to increased risk of fetal growth restriction and stillbirth

questionText: What is the commonest cause of pancreatitis during pregnancy?
What are the patches of light-brown facial pigmentation that commonly develop in women during the third trimester?
Which of the following is NOT a normal change to the skin during pregnancy?
What is the effect of pregnancy on eczema?

answers.answerText: Usually there is an improvement during pregnancy
Usually there is a deterioration during pregnancy
Pregnancy has no effect on eczema
It may progress to become psoriasis
It may progress to become erythema multiforme

questionText: Where does erythema multiforme primarily affect?
Which of the following areas is spared in an eruption of PUPPs? (PUPPs = pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy, also known as polymorphic eruption of pregnancy)
Which of the following are not present in an eruption of PUPPs? (PUPPs = pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy, also known as polymorphic eruption of pregnancy)
What is the incidence of PUPPs? (PUPPs = pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy, also known as polymorphic eruption of pregnancy)
When is the usual onset of PUPPs? (PUPPs = pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy, also known as polymorphic eruption of pregnancy)

answers.answerText: Can occur at any time during pregnancy

questionText: What is the incidence of pemphigoid gestationis (herpes gestationis) in pregnancy?
When is the usual onset of pemphigoid gestationis (herpes gestationis) in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Can occur at any time but the first trimester is the most common time
Can occur at any time but the second trimester is the most common time
Can occur at any time but the third trimester is the most common time
Can occur at any time but post partum is the most common time
Occurs with equal frequency at all stages of pregnancy

questionText: Which of the following is NOT associated with pemphigoid gestationis (herpes gestationis)?
What is the pathogenesis of pemphigoid gestationis (herpes gestationis)?

answers.answerText: Due to the hyperoestrogenaemia of pregnancy
Autoimmune reaction, possibly related to fetal antigens
Occurs secondary to the increased placental production of alkaline phosphatase in pregnancy

questionText: Is pemphigoid gestationis (herpes gestationis) likely to recur in future pregnancies?

answers.answerText: Very unlikely to recur, it if does it is likely to be a milder form
Very unlikely to recur, however if it does it is likely to be more severe
50% chance of recurrence in future pregnancies
Usually recurs but likely to have a milder course
Usually recurs, possibly with an earlier onset and more severe course

questionText: By how much does the plasma volume of blood change in pregnancy?
By how much does the daily requirement for iron increase during pregnancy?
By how much does the daily folate requirement increase during pregnancy?
What is the most common cause of anaemia during pregnancy?
Which of the following is NOT present in iron deficiency anaemia?
Which of the following is true about folate deficiency anaemia?

answers.answerText: Microcytic anaemia with microblastic change in the bone marrow
Macrocytic anaemia with megaloblastic change in the bone marrow
Low MCV, MCH and MCHC are likely to be present
Associated with a reduced total iron binding capacity
Compensatory increase in white blood cell levels occur

questionText: Which of the following is NOT associated with increased blood loss at delivery?
Which of the following is NOT associated with sickle cell disease in pregnancy?

answers.answerText: Increased rate of miscarriage, fetal growth restriction, pre-eclampsia and preterm delivery
Increased risk of perinatal and maternal mortality
Increased risk of placental abruption, fetal distress and requirement for caesarean section
Increased risk of pulmonary thrombosis, thromboembolism and bone marrow embolism
All of the above are associated with sickle cell disease in pregnancy

questionText: Which of the following can precipitate a sickling crisis in a pregnant patient with sickle cell disease?
Which of the following would NOT be expected to be a cause of throbocythemia in a pregnant patient?

answers.answerText: Essential throbocythemia secondary to myeloproliferative disease

questionText: What is the cause off alloimmune thrombocytopenia in pregnancy?
What are the consequences to the mother and/or baby with gestational thrombocytopenia?

answers.answerText: Risk of fetal intracranial haemorrhage, especially if delivery occurs with ventouse
Risk of this condition developing into immune thrombocytopenic purpura

questionText: What are the consequences to a fetus/neonate whose mother is affected immune thrombocytopenia purpura?
What is first line management of gestational thrombocytopenia?
What is first line management of immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
What is the incidence of von Willebrand disease?
What is the function of von Willebrand factor?

answers.answerText: Has a role in platelet function
Plays a role in maintaining the stability of factor VII
Plays a role in maintaining the stability of factor VIII

questionText: What is the abnormality in haemophilia A?
What is the abnormality in haemophilia B?
What is the likelihood of a mother who is a carrier for haemophilia A passing it on to her child (assuming the father does not have a genetic defect)?

answers.answerText: Female infant has a 25% chance of being a carrier, male infant has a 50% chance of being affected with the disease
Female infant has a 50% chance of being a carrier, male infant has a 50% chance of being affected with the disease
Female infant has a 50% chance of being a carrier, male infant has a 100% chance of being affected with the disease

questionText: Which of the following do NOT form part of the classic pentad of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)?

answers.answerText: Haemolytic anaemia with schistocytes on the blood film and thrombocytopenia
